channel.title: T Missile
channel.description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Du8yMsuLQ6Y Watch in HD.
So this is the VFX piece I've been working on lately. I told myself I'd finish it over the break so I did. I was getting tired of tweaking settings, waiting on everything to sim, then watching, then more tweaking, so I decided it's good enough for me.

[/quote]It was taken off the shelves everywhere except the USA last I checked. Which SUCKS for me, I have to make a trip to NY whenever I need it :([/quote]

item.title: T Missile
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

The other things are illuminated, it’s just much more subtle. The hole also wouldn’t be that obvious because it’s very soft light, it would be a dim area, which you can’t see because it’s so fast.

It’s nothing I didn’t do. It’s the physics of light.

And yes, I used to drink Vanilla Coke years ago. It was gone for a while, but I guess it’s back because my mom picked some up.

No Vanilla Coke was drunk during the making of this film. I don’t drink anything like that.

@Bowser: There might be a little one, but I figured with the small explosion it didn’t warrant setting up a fan system to blow air around, especially since I didn’t know exactly when the explosion would happen relative to me.

Read full topic

item.title: T Missile

item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

If discovered one little thing, in an explosion there wouldn’t be a shockwave and wouldn’t this affect light things in the room like the curtains?

Sorry if I’am wrong, you are the pro here.

Read full topic

item.title: T Missile
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:16, topic:285641”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=377762.msg2843448#msg2843448 date=1246122220]

The actual explosion doesn’t. It’s actually a frame late.

The wall crumples right as the tip of the missile touches it and because of that you see the missile go a little more, maybe two frames worth.

But the wall lights up as the missile gets close. The explosion doesn’t start until the frame after the tip of the missile is connecting with the wall. Maybe that’s what you’re thinking of.

why would the wall light up if the missile isnt touching it
???
[/quote]
Light from the jet at the rear of the missle?[/quote]
then there would be a hole where theres no light cause the missile blocks it out
also other things would be illuminated…

Read full topic

item.title: T Missile
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

The actual explosion doesn’t. It’s actually a frame late.

The wall crumples right as the tip of the missile touches it and because of that you see the missile go a little more, maybe two frames worth.

But the wall lights up as the missile gets close. The explosion doesn’t start until the frame after the tip of the missile is connecting with the wall. Maybe that’s what you’re thinking of.

item.title: T Missile
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Unhandled:

Dude that is amazing. The camera work is really impressive too, like you would expect in a professional movie.

That’s my nature in photography I guess heh.

In VID101 a quarter or two ago, the first assignment was like the blah blah basic shots. Well all during my video the teacher kept pausing it and was like holy shit that’s a good shot, does anyone know why this was a good shot? And mine was first. It was so awkward the rest of class cause during everyone else’s videos he was like eh, ok. Hmmm.

_>

Read full topic

item.title: T Missile
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

I’ll do a kinda “making of” workflow because it isn’t all done in one program.

1st: Film.
2nd: Import into Premiere Pro.
3rd: Take into After Effects, deinterlace, mask out the pen in 3rd shot
(I actually threw my pen as a reference, I took it out in After Effects so it wouldn’t look weird with a pen and missile)
4th: Render out lossless avi’s for final composite and image sequences for 3D work.
5th: Image sequence of 2nd shot into Cinema4D. Model missile. Animate it changing. Render out missile with alpha.
6th: Image sequence of 3rd shot into 3DS Max. Camera matching, perspective, etc.
7th: Model kitchen walls, import missile, animate it being thrown.
8th: “Fracture” wall when missile hits, physics simulation of wall breaking.
9th: Attach emitter to missile, tweak, simulate.
10th: Another separate emitter and simulation for the wall explosion. Most of the work was done here, tweaking, getting it to explode correctly and not continue to blow up the rest of the room.
11th: Render out all of this from 3DS Max with alpha channel.
12th: Composite two renders with their respective videos, touch up, and color correction in After Effects.
13th: Export from Premiere Pro.

So yeah. Measurements were taken of the pen, wall, and surroundings so everything is to scale. Reference photos of the pen and an HDRI of the kitchen for the 2nd shot. Reference photos of the wall for the 3rd.

The impact wall was obviously modeled, but I textured it with the reference photos I took. No HDRI for the 3rd shot, but I did reproduce the lighting as well as I could.

Touching up in After Effects at the end included matching the grain of the rendered shots with the originals, and the general (brightness, contrast, saturation) settings of each. More severe touch ups like pseudo-lighting the surroundings with adjustment layers for the explosion because I didn’t model anything else from the kitchen for it.

Anything else?

Read full topic
